texts.definition: Game elements that are actively hindering players to complete game goals.
markups: <style="Definition">Game elements that are actively hindering players to complete game goals.</style>

Many games have game elements that portray people or monsters that try and hinder players' goals. These Enemies can actively resist players' intentions through actions or they can be an explanation for challenges or obstacles in the Game World.

Early video games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pac-Man">Pac-Man</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Space%20Invaders">Space Invaders</link></style> have <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> which provide challenges to the players even though they have a limited set of behaviors. Later games like the first-person shooter <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Doom%20series">Doom series</link></style> and the real-time strategy <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Age%20of%20Empires%20series">Age of Empires series</link></style> have many types of <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> that players need to face.

All the infected in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style> are enemies to the players, although some are possible to avoid by not disturbing them. The same applies to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Assassin's%20Creed%202">Assassin's Creed 2</link></style> although this game allows more options for avoiding confrontation, e.g. distracting guards with hired thieves or courtesans as well as bribing heralds to stop being wanted by the authorities.

In fighting games, e.g. the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Soul%20Calibur%20series">Soul Calibur</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tekken%20series">Tekken series</link></style>, players choose one of the available character to then meet another as an <style="CurrentLink">Enemy</style> controlled either by another player or the computer. Similar structures exist in death-match versions in first-person shooters, e.g. the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Doom%20series">Doom</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quake%20series">Quake series</link></style>, and those game in the genre specifically designed for team play, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Return%20to%20Castle%20Wolfenstein:%20Enemy%20Territory">Return to Castle Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlefield%20series">Battlefield series</link></style>.

Several games, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Super%20Mario%20series">Super Mario series</link></style>, let players know who the main <style="CurrentLink">Enemy</style> is but only makes it possible to actively fight him or her at the end. A version of this is to let players know that there is an enemy but only reveal its identity when one can act against it.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Space%20Alert">Space Alert</link></style> shows how <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> can exist in games as more abstract challenges that need to be overcome, in this case card representing threats that players need to work together against to beat.

<style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> may be added to <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> to provide <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conflicts">Conflicts</link></style> in otherwise <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style>-based games or to create <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style>, but is a necessity in <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style> that wish to have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conflicts">Conflicts</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> in the form of <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="generic-adversaries">Generic Adversaries</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> that have <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="capture">Capture</link></style> goals aimed at the player is a typically way of creating <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> with diegetic presence in a <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style> but <style="Link"><link="game-system-player">Game System Player</link></style> provides another option. By this they are natural ways of providing players with ways of interacting with them and understanding how the <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> can effect the environment and the players. <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> can however be indirectly present through how they create challenges to players, e.g. through <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> or by activating <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style>, which in these cases are also typically accompanied by narrative explanations, e.g. through <style="Link"><link="cutscenes">Cutscenes</link></style>. This indirect approach is especially common when the final <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> are <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style> which the players only get to directly struggle again at the end of the game, <style="Link"><link="game-boards">Game Boards</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="levels">Level</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> may also only be <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> because they are <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> trying to hinder players' goals toward them, e.g. trying to avoid being the objective in <style="Link"><link="capture">Capture</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="herd">Herd</link></style> goals.

If <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> are permanent or temporary is a basic design choice regarding their use. Permanent <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> can be used as the main driving force for <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> and make the gameplay clearer as their role does not change, and making these <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> into <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> puts the designers in control of their impact on gameplay. The <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> do not have to be present at the start of the game though, they can either be the result of <style="Link"><link="spawning">Spawning</link></style> or be friendly or neutral entities that at some point change (this being an example of a <style="Link"><link="irreversible-events">Irreversible Event</link></style>),  e.g. related to a <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style> goal. <style="Link"><link="ever-increasing-difficulty">Ever Increasing Difficulty</link></style> can through this be added to a game by guaranteeing that more and more <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> or more and more powerful <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> oppose players as gameplay progresses.

The same options regarding when the entities become hostile apply to temporary <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style>. In addition, these need either a fixed limitation on how long the hostile stance is maintained (which gives rise to an <style="Link"><link="ultra-powerful-events">Ultra-Powerful Event</link></style> and provides a basis for a <style="Link"><link="time-limits">time-limited</link></style> <style="Link"><link="survive">Survive</link></style> goal) or have rules for determining when the change occur. Thus, player may have the options of choosing if they want to try to make <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> into <style="Link"><link="helpers">Helpers</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style>, or turning them into <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style>. This is typically a <style="Link"><link="trade-offs">Trade-Off</link></style>.

The cause for enmity between the player and the <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> can usually be described through a Goal/<style="Link"><link="preventing-goals">Preventing Goal</link></style> pair. Such an overarching goal can then be used to create numerous subgoals within <style="Link"><link="goal-hierarchies">Goal Hierarchies</link></style>: a <style="Link"><link="collections">Collections</link></style> of goals that consist of several duels, <style="Link"><link="gain-information">Gain Information</link></style> goals to gain the identity of the <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> or their <style="Link"><link="vulnerabilities">Vulnerabilities</link></style> (or <style="Link"><link="achilles-heels">Achilles' Heels</link></style>), <style="Link"><link="overcome">Overcome</link></style> to defeat the henchmen of the <style="CurrentLink">Enemy</style>, <style="Link"><link="supporting-goals">Supporting Goals</link></style> to find the <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style>, or learn the <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style> for defeating the <style="CurrentLink">Enemy</style>, and so on. However, causes compatible with the diegesis need to be found to explain why these <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> cannot be encountered early in the game if <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> is to be maintained. For <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mutual%20Enemies">Mutual Enemies</link></style> can be created by making them hostile towards sets of players (and thereby suggesting <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Alliances">Alliances</link></style> if <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> are not already present). Sometimes <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> can be simply created through providing <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Inhabitants">Inhabitants</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="loot">Loot</link></style>.

For game elements to be able to function as <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> they need some way of negatively effecting players. Actions that allow <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> and can remove <style="Link"><link="health">Health</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style> (and thereby threatening <style="Link"><link="survive">Survive</link></style> goals) are the most common, but those giving players <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> offer alternatives that do not diegetically imply <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style> goals. Since these action reduce players' <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> can often be seen as a form of <style="Link"><link="consumers">Consumers</link></style>. Giving the <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> the possibility of doing the actions players can may be required to provide <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style>, e.g. <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> without the possibility for <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> are in themselves typically not a challenge against players that control <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> that can move.

Another primary design choice when defining <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> is how players can <style="Link"><link="overcome">Overcome</link></style> or avoid them after they have begun to actively oppose them. There may be many ways to do this, which may change during gameplay, often mirroring the way the <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> can effect the players. For example, <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style> goals can allow players to avoid <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> the <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> can cause but only if these are caused by them succeeding with <style="Link"><link="aim-shoot">Aim & Shoot</link></style> actions, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Connection">Connection</link></style> goals, or similar (and for this reason this pattern is seen as modulating <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style> rather than instantiating it - it is the threat of <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> that is more important). For more challenging <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style>, and especially <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style>, players may have to complete several subgoals before having the chance to challenge the <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> at all. Typical ways of overcoming Enemies are by <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Elimination</link></style> (most often in the form of <style="Link"><link="aim-shoot">Aim & Shoot</link></style> as in first-person shooters such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Doom%20series">Doom series</link></style>), by permanently making <style="Link"><link="interferable-goals">Interferable Goals</link></style> impossible or by converting through succeeding with <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style> goals. <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style> is a way to use <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> as a way restrict the ways <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> can struggle against each other. Related to overcoming <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> is the effect of doing so has. Besides fulfilling any eventual goals, the handing out of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Experience%20Points">Experience Points</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="loot">Loot</link></style> are common design solutions (and may be expected by players in certain genres, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Roleplaying%20Games">Roleplaying Games</link></style>) and the latter makes <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> into potential <style="Link"><link="resource-sources">Resource Sources</link></style>.

For <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> to actively oppose players they do need some kind of behavior, which can either be controlled by humans or by predetermined structures (i.e. <style="Link"><link="algorithmic-agents">Algorithmic Agents</link></style>). Other humans (as players or <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style>) ofter the most unpredictable behavior, so in many cases the most challenging <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> are found in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> but <style="Link"><link="algorithmic-agents">Algorithmic Agents</link></style> can also be made very challenging by having <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> or more information (i.e. the game has <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asymmetric%20Information">Asymmetric Information</link></style>), but this easily conflicts with players' sense of <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style> and quite likely also with <style="Link"><link="determinable-chance-succeed">Determinable Chance to Succeed</link></style>, especially when this makes the effect of the <style="Link"><link="algorithmic-agents">Algorithmic Agents'</link></style> actions into <style="Link"><link="ultra-powerful-events">Ultra-Powerful Events</link></style>. By definition, <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> can provide unbeatable <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> since they can enforce <style="Link"><link="ultra-powerful-events">Ultra-Powerful Events</link></style> whenever they wish, but this is tempered by their assumed goal of making players have somewhat of a <style="Link"><link="determinable-chance-succeed">Determinable Chance to Succeed</link></style> and an <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style>.

The difficulty of <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> can be modulated by giving them <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> compared to other <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style>, and this is one way to create <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style> - the other being to create powerful <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style> as <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style>. Specific ways of improving <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> includes changing their <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Stats">Stats</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style>, equipping them with <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style> (that can become <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> if they are <style="Link"><link="transferable-items">Transferable Items</link></style>), giving them <style="Link"><link="privileged-movement">Privileged Movement</link></style> compared to the players, penalizing players with <style="Link"><link="no-ops">No-Ops</link></style>, or simply changing how many <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> are met. All these can be used to provide <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style>, and this be further increase (and adding <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style>) by using <style="Link"><link="orthogonal-differentiation">Orthogonal Differentiation</link></style> to give different <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> different abilities. One example of this is the inclusion of the Arch-vile in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Doom%202">Doom 2</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Doom%203">Doom 3</link></style> which can revive other dead <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> or summon more respectively, and the priest of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Age%20of%20Empires">Age of Empires</link></style> and monks of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Age%20of%20Empires%202">Age of Empires 2</link></style> that can convert enemy <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="invulnerabilities">Invulnerabilities</link></style> can easily make <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> hard - or too hard - to <style="Link"><link="overcome">Overcome</link></style> but can be used to force non-violent solutions; For <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style> the pattern can also be used to force players to first complete a sub goal which makes them vulnerable. <style="Link"><link="vulnerabilities">Vulnerabilities</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="achilles-heels">Achilles' Heels</link></style> can instead make the <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> easier to <style="Link"><link="overcome">Overcome</link></style> as can <style="Link"><link="no-ops">No-Ops</link></style> applied on them, but these may require players to complete <style="Link"><link="gain-information">Gain Information</link></style> goals first. <style="Link"><link="achilles-heels">Achilles' Heels</link></style> can also required players' to engage in <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style> to take advantage of the enemy weaknesses. <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style> in the form of their appearances, behavior and the <style="Link"><link="traces">Traces</link></style> they have left in the game environment can help support this search for information. <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> can of course also be applied on the factors which determines the <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> difficulty. When this is done, it introduces <style="Link"><link="uncertainty-information">Uncertainty of Information</link></style> and a certain level of <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style>, and can motivate <style="Link"><link="gain-information">Gain Information</link></style> goals.

Since setting the right difficulty of enemies can be hard to in advanced, especially with games which supports <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style>, it may be desired to be able to adjust the difficulty in direct conjunction to the gameplay. <style="Link"><link="difficulty-levels">Difficulty Levels</link></style> put this in the hands of the players and can let them choose between <style="Link"><link="casual-gameplay">Casual</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style> if the range of difficulties is large enough. <style="Link"><link="dynamic-difficulty-adjustment">Dynamic Difficulty Adjustment</link></style> makes use of algorithms to modify the difficulty of the game during gameplay depending on player performance or number of players. <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> can modulate players' <style="Link"><link="determinable-chance-succeed">Determinable Chance to Succeed</link></style> not only on their actual chance to succeed but also what the players believe, but may also do so after the players have performed actions through <style="Link"><link="fudged-results">Fudged Results</link></style>.

Another aspect of <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> is if they always behave in the same way or if they have different set of behaviors. Having <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> in passive states, as for example some of the infected in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style>, can provide players the opportunity to have a <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> between <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="conceal">Conceal</link></style> (and thereby <style="Link"><link="stealth">Stealth</link></style>) goals. The same goes for <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> that patrol areas with <style="Link"><link="guard">Guard</link></style> goals, except that this create more <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style>. Players may not need to choose any of these, but if the <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> populate the environment needed to cross to complete <style="Link"><link="traverse">Traverse</link></style> goals, a choice can be forced from them. Games providing these different states have the possibility of using <style="Link"><link="alarms">Alarms</link></style>, either as <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style> which players can set off or to give players the <style="Link"><link="preventing-goals">Preventing Goals</link></style> of hindering the <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> to activate the <style="Link"><link="alarms">Alarms</link></style> when they have detected something. <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> that flee when hurt or outnumbered may provide <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> while at the same time also making it possible to have <style="Link"><link="capture">Capture</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style> goals before they heal, regroup, or get reinforcements. Passive <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> also allow players to try and engage in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Stealing">Stealing</link></style> <style="Link"><link="transferable-items">Transferable Items</link></style> from them.

Where <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> are met in <style="Link"><link="game-boards">Game Board</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="levels">Level</link></style> also need to be considered since placing them in features such as <style="Link"><link="galleries">Galleries</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="sniper-locations">Sniper Locations</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Strongholds">Strongholds</link></style> can make them much more difficult to <style="Link"><link="overcome">Overcome</link></style>. Their location may be fixed or based upon <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style>, and can be done either so that the <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> are placed before gameplay begin or as <style="Link"><link="game-element-insertion">Game Element Insertion</link></style> during gameplay through <style="Link"><link="spawning">Spawning</link></style> at <style="Link"><link="spawn-points">Spawn Points</link></style>. Their appearance to players may be explain through <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> or through <style="Link"><link="alien-space-bats">Alien Space Bats</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="waves">Waves</link></style> can also be used to introduce many <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> are specific points or at specific intervals at <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> while <style="Link"><link="laning">Laning</link></style> can make their appearance predictable but still allow for different choices of tactics and strategies. They can also be used to ensure <style="Link"><link="ever-increasing-difficulty">Ever Increasing Difficulty</link></style> due to steadily increasing numbers and difficulties of <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style>.

They may block paths to <style="Link"><link="traverse">Traverse</link></style> goal (especially easy at <style="Link"><link="choke-points">Choke Points</link></style>), may make areas into <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style>, may be the objectives of <style="Link"><link="reconnaissance">Reconnaissance</link></style> goals as long as there is <style="Link"><link="uncertainty-information">Uncertainty of Information</link></style> regarding their location, or may be <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">Game World Exploration</link></style> goals. In games requiring <style="Link"><link="maneuvering">Maneuvering</link></style> they can provide additional hazards that have to be actively avoided. Used together with <style="Link"><link="galleries">Galleries</link></style> or other types of areas that have <style="Link"><link="choke-points">Choke Points</link></style> they can effectively create <style="Link"><link="conditional-passageways">Conditional Passageways</link></style>. These in turn can create (temporary) <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style> until the <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> have been dealt with. <style="Link"><link="sniper-locations">Sniper Locations</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Strongholds">Strongholds</link></style> can also create <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style> but in these cases this is not so much an effect of <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> being denied as easily being eliminated while moving.

Some <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style>, typically <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style>, are large enough to be <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style>. Examples of this include the Colossi in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Shadow%20of%20the%20Colossus">Shadow of the Colossus</link></style> and some of the <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style> in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/God%20of%20War%20series">God of War series</link></style>. As mentioned above, having several <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> appear at the same time is an easy way to make the encounters more difficulty (and may demand <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attention%20Swapping">Attention Swapping</link></style>), but having <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> appear separated allows players to decide what <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> to challenge first (which can be useful to counter <style="Link"><link="orthogonal-differentiation">Orthogonal Differentiation</link></style>) and provides <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style>.

Typically <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> are clearly differentiated from other game elements through shape and color to help make them into <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style> so players become aware of them. However, by presenting the <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> in ways suitable, players can have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Identification">Identification</link></style> with them it can create a form of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Dilemma">Social Dilemma</link></style> as can having to perform certain actions to <style="Link"><link="overcome">Overcome</link></style> the <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style>.

Many games show <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> to the players through <style="Link"><link="cutscenes">Cutscenes</link></style> before they can interact as a way of presenting <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>, and this is especially common with <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> are integral to many game themes and therefore necessary for a game's <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>. They may however also need to be modulated according to a game's theme for players to recognize them as <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style>. While <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> with goals to <style="Link"><link="capture">Capture</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="herd">Herd</link></style> game elements belonging to the player make them <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style>, <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> can also become <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> because players have the goals concerning them. In general, <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> not controlled by other players create <style="Link"><link="pve">PvE</link></style> gameplay.

<style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> give rise to <style="Link"><link="preventing-goals">Preventing Goals</link></style> for a player, not only in the sense that the player oppose the <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> goals but also in the sense that the <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> oppose the player's goals. The presence of <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> causes <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> and gives players motivation for <style="Link"><link="overcome">Overcome</link></style> goals, often through <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="capture">Capture</link></style>, but sometimes through succeeding in <style="Link"><link="herd">Herd</link></style> goals through <style="Link"><link="maneuvering">Maneuvering</link></style>. As such, they naturally cause <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conflicts">Conflicts</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Competition">Competition</link></style> as they threaten to make the players lose <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> (working as a form of <style="Link"><link="consumers">Consumers</link></style>), or otherwise block the players' progress in the game.  <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> with <style="Link"><link="reconnaissance">Reconnaissance</link></style> goals can give rise to both <style="Link"><link="conceal">Conceal</link></style> goals for players and the need for <style="Link"><link="rhythm-based-actions">Rhythm-Based Actions</link></style>.

The presence of <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> introduces disturbances, so in this sense they modulate or even counter <style="Link"><link="camping">Camping</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style> by making it more difficult or impossible. However, if players have control over when and how they encounter the <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style>, or if they have <style="Link"><link="vulnerabilities">Vulnerabilities</link></style> or the environment contains <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style>, this may encourage and modulate <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style> and indirectly promote a certain level of <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style>. A special case of this can be seen in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, where if players can identify <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mutual%20Enemies">Mutual Enemies</link></style> this may form the motivation for creating <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Alliances">Alliances</link></style>. Testing and confirming that <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> actually have <style="Link"><link="vulnerabilities">Vulnerabilities</link></style> leads to <style="Link"><link="experimenting">Experimenting</link></style> -  this also happens with <style="Link"><link="achilles-heels">Achilles' Heels</link></style> but then may more take the aspect of <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style>.

The appearance of <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> are nearly always <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Disruption%20of%20Focused%20Attention">Disruption of Focused Attention</link></style> events or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style>. The presence of them in turn create <style="Link"><link="attention-demanding-gameplay">Attention Demanding Gameplay</link></style> and can require <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attention%20Swapping">Attention Swapping</link></style> when several different groups of <style="CurrentLink">Enemies</style> exist.
